text: [Music]
hi everyone i'm nate p trustmoreland and today i'm presenting hacking the voter
lessons from a decade of russian military operations over the next 35 minutes i'll cover what
prompted today's talk the importance of the information space in russian strategic thought
how this thinking plays out in russian military election interference operations and what we should be doing based on
these insights as a brief introduction i want to point out a few parts of my bio that i think
are relevant to today i have a little hands-on experience with elections having done field organizing
on the 2008 obama for america campaign after that youthful diversion i did
graduate research at yale on chinese cyber strategy and have since worked at
booz allen on cti for more than a decade running several ocean teams and
presently serving as the head of strategic cyber threat intelligence as you can see my academic background in
history in international relations is not technology this is translated to a research focus
on looking for not just the how of cyber operations but the bigger picture
why like why conduct a particular operation in the first place when an adversary
could be doing anything else why take action at any given time
like why release stolen documents open breakers or release wipers on one day as
opposed to any other day once you have the ability to do so
why use these tactics how does this help achieve whatever goal
the adversary has what was the objective like what was the point of it all
and how does this operation relate to other ones not just in terms of tactics but also the motivation
today's presentation was inspired by a report my company published in march that tried to answer those questions
we synthesized more than 15 years of publicly documented activity attributed to russia's military espionage and
special forces agency the gru we wanted to figure out what the gru was
thinking to do this we essentially took them at their word you see public russian policy documents
detail the military's high-level logic and world view they describe what prompts the military
to take action and how the military sees its tactics advancing its mission the gru's mission
is to identify and then neutralize or counter threats to russian national security interests
very long story short the gru has been doing essentially what the military says it's going to do
today's presentation draws on the report's findings to narrowly look at one gru focus
elections now russian covert election influence
activities didn't start in the cyber era the soviet union's intelligence agency
is engaged in covert election interference as far back as the 1920s and sarah the case of washington senator
henry scoop jackson in 1976 he ran for the democratic party's nomination
for president he was a russia hardliner and so according to archival kgb documents
the soviet union aimed to derail his candidacy at the time the kgb frustratingly noted
that he had never been involved in any major political or personal scandal so they went digging for dirt they
looked everywhere even digging down records in norway where his family had migrated from almost 100 years
earlier eventually they settled on discrediting him by portraying him as being secretly gay
he had married late in life and earlier in his career rumors had circulated in dc that he was a
confirmed bachelor having lived with male roommates at times
so the kgb forged several documents to confirm this narrative including a memo from fbi director j
edgar hoover the kgb then sent the files to newspapers and his political opponents
as far as i can tell the files were never published but jackson's campaign failed to gain
traction regardless in short russian foreign election interference
isn't new nor are many of their fundamental strategies what has changed is who's doing it and what
tools they use in september 1985 then cia deputy director for intelligence robert gates
told congress that the primary soviet organizations responsible for foreign political influence activities
were the kgb and the soviet communist party's political organizing and propaganda
departments so then the question arises how did covert election interference become a
military mission to answer those questions a good place to start is the late 1990s
around this time russian foreign policy elites began to coalesce around a concept called
informatsone protifoborstvo commonly translated as information
confrontation this argues that international relations are fundamentally a struggle between
states over what is known perceived believed and felt for those of you kremlinologists
concerned with the russian psyche the choice of word protivo borztebo is interesting it connotes a sense of
fighting in opposition rather than a clash of two systems suggesting a world view of russia
responding to an informational assault hence a more literal translation is closer to an
informational counteraction the struggle is continuous existing beyond traditional concepts of
delineated war and peace for this reason the sometimes translation of the term as information
warfare can mislead about the concept as it erroneously suggests that russo perceived
itself as being in a uniquely heightened state of conflict a wartime battlefield clash of armies so
to speak represents just a fraction of modern military engagement former chief of the military's general
staff yuri bolyevsky noted in a 2017 interview that quote the victory over
the enemy in this conflict can be much more important than victory in a classical military conflict
because it is bloodless yet the impact is overwhelming and can paralyze
all of the enemy state's power structures in short then international relations
for russia is a conflict over the political or national capacity to oppose ignore
or support its agenda contrast the sweeping concept of a nation struggling for an advantage
in the information space with the much narrower and more siloed western concept of agencies and
organizations securing cyberspace the russian military buys into
information confrontation here's something they wrote in 2000 in the national
information security doctrine quote information conflict is the
confrontation between two or more states in the information space with the purpose of inflicting damage to
information systems processes and resources critical and other structures
undermining the political economic and social systems a massive psychological manipulation of
the population to destabilize the state in society as well as coercing
the state to take decisions for the benefit of the opposing force similar language has continued to
permeate military documents from you know through the present day furthermore it's helpfully defined by
the russian military's website this is why according to its doctrine
the russian military's responsibilities now include protecting russian historical spiritual and
patriotic traditions and guarding against russian cultural strife
that's hardly the stuff of traditional western concepts of military security generally defined as defending against
armed foreign aggression and the ability to enforce policy through the use of force
now russian strategists note that the information conflict is waged with two classes of capabilities
first informational psychological which controls the information itself informational technical which controls
the systems by which information is held transmitted or processed it's probably
not a coincidence then that the two primary activity groups within the gru best known to the public as apt
28 and sandworm closely aligned with the psychological and technical capabilities
generally speaking then apt-28 operations control the information environment with
espionage data leaks and disinformation sandworm however controls the
information environment with destruction and disruption
the goal of the information conflict is shaping national psyches and perceptions over the long
run for this reason achieving quantifiable measurable traditional victories probably are not
the whole game what about swinging outcomes this is probably an ideal result
where some certain candidates are elected and referendums are not passed however in an information conflict it
needn't be the only winning scenario furthermore numerous studies have shown that moscow's likely preferred
candidates have rarely won despite russian interference other valuable impacts of information
operations include one the clash of power information operations undermined social
cohesion and tarnished the reputation of opponents leaders and institutions thereby russia weakens the ability of
its opponents to lead their own countries as well as to build and lead international institutions and
coalitions like the eu and nato thus by shaping the information
landscape russia diminishes the ability of its opponents to oppose it second these operations are
opportunistic they serve to periodically shake the dynamics of international relations to
create new opportunities for russian influence many political scientists describe
international relations as being like a high-powered card game you can peek at your opponent's cards
signal like i have a great card signal cards or change the game in your favor perhaps by shuffling the deck
i see or i think that we're seeing russia playing with a weak hand of hard
and soft power capabilities so it may be attempting to disrupt the fundamental dynamics where the
proverbial deck can feel stacked against it thirdly information operations may have
a domestic angle remember that an information conflict is both offensive and defensive election
interference likely in part serves to maintain the current leadership in russia the resulting narratives perhaps serve
to signal to russians that fair free and truly competitive democratic systems are not desirable
or perhaps not even possible with these ideas of information
confrontation in mind let's see how that perspective has shaped several gru election interference
operations in february 2014 after several months of protests
a popular uprising known as the euro maidan overthrew ukraine's pro-russia president viktor yanukovych
sending him fleeing to russia mass demonstrations denounce his resistance to closer eu ties and is fostering of
widespread oligarchic corruption the revolution then installed a new government that was eager to politically
militarily and economically distance itself from russia immediately signaling its intention to
join the eu and it was soon after muse about pursuing a nato membership
this was a huge problem for russia russia declared that the new government was illegitimate
furthermore moscow claimed that the new ukrainian government was comprised of extreme ukrainian nationalists quote fascists
nazis neo-nazis and anti-semites end quote who would persecute ethnic russians and
other ethnic minorities russia promptly responded by using gru's special forces wearing unmarked uniforms
to destabilize eastern ukraine and annex the crimean peninsula well given that yanukovych had left the
country it was necessary to hold a presidential election which was scheduled for may 25th according to ukraine's cert
in mid-march just as russian forces were rolling in the gru began laying the technical
groundwork to interfere with the election the plan went into action just days
before the election details what exactly unfolded have become a little confused and available
public sources but as best as i can determine here's what happened
on may 22nd the gru used a wiper with hard-coded administrative passwords to
disrupt systems at ukraine's central election commission the cec according to ukraine's national
security service the sbu the attackers appeared to focus on the elections
analytics system used to aggregate voter data about 20 hours later the cec was up and
running again having restored from backups on the morning of may 23rd the gru in
the guise of hacktivist cyberbear coupe published a statement claiming to have destroyed the cec's vote counting system
as proof they provided plenty of internal data such as admin passwords and network diagrams
the ukrainian government about an hour or so later issued two statements the cec attested that there had been
some technical problems quote unquote in the elections and voting systems
and functionality had been fully restored the sbu noted that they had discovered and stopped what sounds like
a logic bomb that would have gone off on election day and destroyed the elections results
the sbu blamed conspirators working with the yanukovych government for the attack
the next day march 24th the personal website of interior minister arson
alvakov was modified with a statement about the attack the blog post indicated that cec vote
counting systems had been destroyed and could not be recovered by the election nevertheless
the election could process and proceed with an entirely manual vote count the
statement blamed the situation on the criminal negligence of certain cec officials and bemoaned
the security agencies had been slow to release appropriate details russian government media like rt and
arya navosti picked up on this apparent confirmation amplifying it
later that day avocados official facebook account stated that his website had been defaced
and disavowed the content quote they posted fake statements by me
about the election it's fake aimed at creating information chaos and disrupting the
normal election process he further noted that cec was functioning and the election would occur
normally then came election day march 25th that morning cyber recruit
leaked emails allegedly showing an attempt by government officials to boost correct candidates in the election the documents
allegedly contained instructions to ensure the victory of an extremist ukrainian nationalist political group
affiliated with pravi sector a fringe political party and paramilitary group
election day thus proceeded throughout the day the cec's website showed various 404 not
found errors then 12 and between 12 and 40 minutes
before polls closed at 8 pm that evening the cec website was defaced to show that
exactly as russia and the cyber burkhood fake divis had warned a fringe nationalist candidate
representing the province sector party had inconceivably won the election with 37
percent of the vote this was impressive because he had been pulling in just the single digits
days earlier the vote rigging cyber burkuk claimed would happen appeared to
have come to pass immediately russian state broadcast or channel 1
relayed the results in a live news bulletin further adding a sheen of authenticity but this wasn't the end as the manual
vote trickled in that night the gr use launched a ddos against
the vote towing system from three one to three am local time hindering the transfer of vote tallies
from ukraine's districts to the cec thereby further delaying the publication of the real vote
side note in fact the province sector candidate had actually come in 11th place with less than 1 percent of
the vote in sum russia had dominated the information landscape through a
carefully planned operation and identified narratives that threatened the perceived fairness of the
election and legitimacy of the government as well as issues that divided the ukrainian people
it then took steps to cede evidence through technical and psychological means to support these narratives
and hinder its opponent's ability to respond to quote the immortal 1984 fantasy film
the dungeon master the gru had declared i reject your reality and insert my
own in 2015 bulgaria held a two-round country-wide local election
at the time the country's ruling party had taken a policy tact of distancing bulgaria from russia on a
promise of benefits of closer alignment with the west earlier that year the government had
denied the russian military access to bulgarian airspace citing its objection to russia's bombing
campaigns in syria in this context the election was seen as a referendum on the country's
ruling coalition distancing from russia the bulgarian government alleges that
the gru attempted to interfere with this election on october 25th the first round of
voting massive ddos attacks hit government websites the ddos hit the interior ministry
foreign ministry the central election commission and the government organization that tells voters their polling station
and their voter registration status according to the election commission the traffic on their website was
equivalent to 65 million active sessions at once that's
mighty impressive for a country with a population of only 7 million people
the ddos reportedly changed multiple times in apparent response to the site administrators varying their defenses
leading government officials to hypothesize that maybe insiders were providing information on counter
measures a week later during the second voting round another smaller ddos targeted the
cec and the bulgarian president's website in some these operations appear designed to
block access to key authoritative sources of information about the election as no counter narrative appeared to our
knowledge it's possible that the attack may have variously served to frustrate bulgarian voters raise concerns about
legitimacy of their vote and impose costs on their leadership by the way the voters rallied around the
pro-western government expanding its repute its representation in local governments throughout bulgaria
in november 2016 france's centrist finance minister emmanuel macron joined a crowded field of candidates for
the may 2017 presidential election at the time the leading candidate appeared to be marine
le pen an overtly pro-russia anti-eu candidate macron a dark horse candidate rapidly
gained in the polls and became a leading candidate by the end of the year just behind le pen
macron had not positioned himself as being particularly anti-russia he but he did however threaten russian
strategic interests by being a fervent supporter of the eu and internationalism in december as
macron rose in the polls the gru began fishing macron's campaign and in february the campaign publicly accused russia of
attempting to breach its systems concurrently pro-kremlin media blasted
macron with constantly changing allegations including among other things that he was
secretly gay an american spy being supported by a global cabal of jewish bankers
you name it it probably didn't matter if the public accepted any given falsehood
but rather that they felt there was something unsavory about macron given all these stories they'd heard
on may 3rd an anonymous user posted documents on 4chan reporting to show
that macron had an undisclosed offshore account in the bahamas le pen
referenced the documents in that evening's debate security researchers later assessed that the documents may
have been forged or digitally manipulated versions of real documents on may 5th the leaker published a higher
resolution version of the document as well as 9 gigabytes of macron campaign communications
this news was amplified on social media by leak sites fringe political commentators and
accounts displaying bot-like behavior note that france has a legal moratorium
on campaigning and campaign press coverage during the final 48 hours prior to national
elections the leaks went viral before that deadline although the macron campaign was able to
issue a brief statement before the deadline french media were largely unable to comment on the leak
the campaign also had an informational technical opponent about which much less is publicly known the nsa has
publicly confirmed in general terms that russian hackers had penetrated some french infrastructure related to the election
montenegro has a complex relationship with russia russia promotes the country's shared
orthodox heritage invests heavily in many sectors and sends tourists to account for a quarter montenegro's
visitors despite these overtures montenegro has followed a clearly pro-west trajectory
the country is headed towards eu membership and most relevant to this example joined nato in 2017. in october 2016
montenegro held parliamentary elections that would determine whether the pro-west government would remain in power
and complete its nato membership process preventing the expansion of nato is a core
russian national security concern according to montenegro and the united kingdom russia attempted to disrupt this pivotal
election in a manner similar to what happened in bulgaria on the three days leading up to
the election russian operators allegedly directed ddos attacks disrupted media websites the companies
the country's largest telecom negrin telecom a democracy promoting
non-governmental organization or ngo that was promoting the election and the ruling pro-nato party
additional unattributed ddos attacks targeted the montenegrin government's web portal for two days following the
election in addition to this russia attempted to manipulate montenegro's political and
social environment by allegedly funneling money into opposition political groups and seeking to coordinate with politicians
clergy ngos and media outlets most disturbingly the gru allegedly
planned to use political violence montenegro claims that the gru had recruited serbian nationals to dress in
police uniforms and occupy parliament on the night of the election a russia-friendly political party would
then use messaging services like whatsapp to call upon its members to storm the building the fake police would then fire
upon the protesters sparking an anti-government groundswell and thus prevent the real election winners from taking power
the coup thankfully didn't occur montenegrin law enforcement acting on tips from several nato countries
arrested two gru officers and their agents shortly before the election furthermore the montenegrin government
preemptively blocked national access to whatsapp and viber on election day
now of course we can't talk about gru election interference without discussing
the 2016 us presidential election rather than rehash all of the tactics
let's put a few in the light of information confrontation and the other examples we just discussed
the gru used many tactics we just examined to control and manipulate the information environment around the us's
election the gru stole emails working documents and other sensitive data
and laundered it into the american public discourse the group published directly through
personas like cyberbrick dc leaks and guccifer or guccifer
2.0 and like-minded leak sites the gru also reached out to journalists
politically connected individuals and other shapers of american public discourse who published commented on and amplified
these leaks and the narratives associated with them the gru attempted to convince americans
that their elections were rigged leaking emails from democratic party leaders and members of the media
which the gru claimed was evidence of coordinated coordinated favoritism for candidate
clinton this sure sounds a lot like those emails the gru leaked on the morning of the 2014 ukrainian election
the other half of this campaign the informational technical aspects however i think haven't received enough
attention that summer and fall the gre breached or conducted reconnaissance at numerous
elections infrastructure targets last year the senate's intel committee concluded that gru operators had
performed reconnaissance on and in some cases attempted to access elections related networks and
infrastructure in all 50 u.s states they targeted state voter registration
databases state and local voting databases a vendor of software used to verify
voter registration data and election administration organizations and personnel other than
exfiltrating some voter registration data which is generally public information to begin with there's no reporting that they
did anything with their access but the ground was set to so fear
uncertainty and doubt about voter access and the legitimacy of the vote perhaps not coincidentally that summer
inauthentic social media accounts linked to the ira or the russian troll farm amplified
statements by leaders of american public discourse that there was going to be large-scale
voter fraud and vote rigging finally what does russia do when it gets caught
in the cold war the soviets often responded to foreign criticism by charging its critics with doing the same
thing you call us human rights violators are you not a country that lynches black
people russia and the gru did the same thing when russia's state-sponsored doping
program was uncovered they leaked medical use exemptions of athletes from russia's
rivals to which russian diplomats literally tweeted an image of the word hypocrisy
well based on the mueller report on june 6 the gru intrusion at the dnc reached its
high watermark and four days later the remediation phase of the breach response began kicking them out of the
network the gre had already been caught and needed to get ahead of the news
that they were interfering in the election perhaps not coincidentally on june 7th gru front dc leaks began
leaking data from democratic or from a democracy promotion group open societies foundation which is
funded by george soros dc leaks noted that its information its data showed
that quote soros is named an architect and a sponsor of almost every revolution and coup around the
world for the past 25 years the usa is thought to be a vampire due to him and his puppets not a
lighthouse of freedom and democracy then in october after the us publicly
accused russia of interfering in the election the gru struck again as cyber burkut it leaked data from the
national endowment for democracy a federally funded democracy promotion group this leak went right to the heart of
russia's counter-narrative according to cyberbear cout their leaks allegedly revealed covert u.s operations
to stoke protest movements and influence elections worldwide with an emphasis on upsetting the
russian political order in short the narrative is how can the u.s
say that russia is a bad guy for meddling in u.s elections if u.s funded groups also attempt to
influence elections now now that we've looked at what the
gru has done during elections let's consider how they could reapply their other information confrontation tactics
to elections we've shown today that russian operations often play into existing
narratives consider them that in the last year alone ransomware attacks impacted more
than 100 u.s state and local government we know that the gre sand worm group really likes to use wiper malware and
has designed it sometimes to look like ransomware such as in the not petty and bad rabbit campaigns
it would be conceivable that this scourge of criminal ransomware would provide ample cover for attacking
election infrastructure like state and local elections boards a favorite gru strategy to authenticate
and propagate disinformation is to push information through publicly trusted sources such as government websites and
the media well one tactic the gru has previously used was taking
over a maryland television station's sms alert system using it to send subscribers threatening
text messages seen here this technique may might just as easily
be used to send fake news alerts consider how the gru planned to direct a montenegrin political party to use its
whatsapp group to organize a coup in response to fabricated news
finally let's open the spectrum really wide what else might be possible the gru has
twice disrupted election electric disrupt distribution in ukraine
would there be value in conducting such an attack say during an election i don't mean like a countrywide blackout
but perhaps a low-key targeted disruption in localized swing areas if this were a
country where electronic voting machines are used it would force a last minute switch to paper ballots
it's easy then to imagine long lines of frustrated voters and dimly lit schools and community centers trying to
vote it may be easy to dismiss this as russia risking massive blowback if it were
to do this say in the united states what about other countries such as georgia nato or any of the other non-nato states
with tense russia relations now how can you prepare to defend
against such attacks a good place to start is to recognize that all adversaries including the gru
are goal oriented they typically work backwards from their objective to identify the most likely pathway for
success looking for the biggest bang for their buck consider then what your organization has to offer
don't take it personally oftentimes you may just be a pawn in a larger game
look not just for at your own internal assets like your data and platforms but look at the role you play in
delivering services or value to other organizations and the general public
think about all the downstream parties and processes that you impact then take a step back and
consider what kinds of threat actors may be interested in influencing any of those organizations and operations
many of the gre's operations begin with existing narratives consider the current zeitgeist that
drives popular discourse especially around elections and current polarizing hot button issues
it's much easier to confirm something people already suspect than to introduce new narratives
the gru often seizes on these opportunities to provide new information or amplifies stories that undermine
confidence in and the reputation of leaders democratic institutions and
processes and international partnerships examine how your informational assets or
those of your downstream partners could be used to confirm or amplify damaging rumors divisive narratives and negative
perceptions finally look at campaigns around the world that would be considered
targeting low-risk or traditional targets how are your countries adversaries
already attempting to influence their own populations and their long-standing international
opponents especially those with little power to retaliate operations tend to be bolder when
there's little chance of significant consequences even if the aggressor is ultimately tied to the activity
see montenegro if you know that an actor has a capability or ttp consider it to be fair game potentially
for use in other applications against other countries like yours so in conclusion
election interference isn't just about changing election outcomes attackers maximize the
strategic value of their tactics targets and timing and strategic
opponents demand strategic defenses thank you and i look forward to your questions
hi everyone i hope you enjoyed the talk uh see we've got a lot of questions going on in the q a so
i just want to tackle a few of them here uh so let's see what do we have here we
have a question about uh what are uh some of the other things that
have actually been accomplished here besides actually you know if you're not actually getting your preferred candidates
elected uh so i think one so we of course talked about in the presentation there's
those three categories of uh the of actions that i think the gru
is targeting but i think the most difficult question here is actually evaluating
whether or not uh the gru the russian view about how to take
action whether or not it's actually having an impact you know it's very difficult to say whether
x caused why it's a classical political science problem but to speak anecdotally uh you know i
mean how many of us uh security professionals have been asked by our friends colleagues family uh you know did
you know especially our families the you know did uh did the russians hack the election and
you know there's no actual evidence that i've seen there you know votes were ever changed
in this election uh you know the real vote totals much less in any of these other examples we
looked at but the fact that this question continues to be asked again and again i think
really exemplifies this problem that people did have vote they did have doubts sewn
in their minds and that is a goal that we assess is of the russian uh you know election
interference activities uh so let's see another question
we have uh question what is the role that the us military has in all of this
well i think first and foremost it's that the us military
is an intelligence arm of the united states you know that is task mother thing among other things
with monitoring the capabilities intentions and activities of
its military competitors so um one of the critiques that it would you know you often get out of the
2016 16 election was that the us was you know caught off guard if you watched
chris krebs's presentation earlier today uh you know he was talking about how in
2016 there was just this general perception that there wasn't a threat here in the united states that it wasn't uh
anticipated so something that the military absolutely has to focus on is identifying
what what is next what is the mil what are our for what are the us's foreign adversaries
going to do how are they going to do it and how uh you know and what sort of evidence do we
have you know that can lead us that conclusion and so what we need to do is look at those other
countries uh that are already being targeted those um you know what is china
doing with taiwan what is russia doing in uh eastern europe and in
other countries and how we can use that as opportunities to identify what are uh likely targets in the future
methods that are going to be used so that we can plan at a strategic level for what's next um
let's see questions uh let's see we have a question about how
do we deter uh so deterrence is a really messy
issue in uh in the cyber community because so much what we're dealing with is
subterfuge and espionage uh with a lot of not clear bright lines
so in deterrence it's a matter of shaping your adversary's risk calculus so if one wanted to engage in
deterrence need to be able to clearly state what are your bright lines uh demonstrate you can actually you can
attribute violations of those bright lines and demonstrate that you know you
are willing to follow through and take actions on violations of those bright lines i'll leave it to
the policy makers to decide what those bright lines are but if we if you know any uh country want to
engage in deterrence you have to be able to take action on those three areas
uh let's see what other questions do we have uh
do you have slides and references uh this question do you have slides and references bill this will be available
after the presentation uh let's see other countries i think there was
something about that um
how to deter uh other goals uh has the us
considered using these techniques given perceptions of success
um all right so given the perceived success of the greu and russia's operations in this area are
we at risk of other national actors such as china beginning to adopt the same tactics uh i believe that is something that we
absolutely need to be on the lookout for uh you know they're you know for example
china is something top of mind for me in terms of what has uh what have its
groups been potentially doing to uh in inter-taiwanese relations with hong
kong with other countries uh in terms of say influencing their elections or say more generally about shaping the
information space uh you know in order to take like firm action
uh you know it would be nice to have some public attribution to back it up but so for example the rumors about uh you
know say the wintee group going after the nebulous winte group going after
uh energy groups in uh taiwan uh uh basically
whether or not they're going to engage in more uh destructive activities using more gru
ways of using destructive activities in order to influence uh the you know

all right so you know thank you everyone for uh engaging in this talk today uh if you
